citations.narrative:
An ostrich was euthanized on April 18th, thirteen days after it had grabbed and swallowed a set of keys from one of the
animal care staff who came too close to its enclosure. On April 5th, the keeper was one of two staff members assigned to
secure the zoo for the night. During those rounds, he stopped to take a picture of the ostrich at a section of the enclosure
that is not accessible to the public and has no barriers. The enclosure is constructed with 4” x 4” wire mesh StaTite
fencing. The keeper approached the enclosure fence with his phone in one hand and his set of keys in the other. The
ostrich reached through the enclosure fence and grabbed the keys with its beak. It then lifted its head and swallowed the
keys. The keeper was not part of the ostrich’s care staff and violated zoo policy by closely approaching the ostrich in this
area.
The keeper immediately reported the incident, but despite extensive veterinary care and surgical efforts, the keys were
not retrievable. The animal’s health declined, and she was euthanized.
Handling of zoo animals, which includes nearly every interaction between animals and zoo staff, needs to be carried out
by trained and knowledgeable staff who prioritize animal welfare and safety during all interactions. The handling of all
animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, overheating,
excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
